H0.text: Trenches are the landforms most likely associated with hot spots over which tectonic plates move in certain areas.

H1.text: Volcanoes are the landforms most likely associated with tectonic plates moving over hot spots in certain areas.

H2.text: Island arcs are the landforms most likely associated with hot spots over which tectonic plates move in certain areas.

H3.text: Mid‑ocean ridges are the landforms most likely associated with hot spots when tectonic plates move over them.

A4.text: Volcanoes are formed when tectonic plates move over hot spots, as evidenced by the Hawaiian Islands and the Galápagos, which are volcanic chains created by this process.

A5.text: Mid-ocean ridges are formed by the divergence of tectonic plates, not by movement over hot spots, as they are associated with constructive plate boundaries and seafloor spreading.

A6.text: Trenches are formed by the convergence of tectonic plates, not by movement over hot spots, as they are associated with destructive plate boundaries and subduction zones.

A7.text: Island arcs are formed by the subduction of one tectonic plate beneath another, not by movement over hot spots, as they are associated with convergent plate boundaries.
